4 
[paragraph].7 In describing the anatomy of the Medusae it will be found most 
convenient to commence with the stomach and trace the other organs 
from it. 
<u>of the Stomach<u>. This organ varies <s>both<\s> extremely both in in shape 
and in size in the <u>Cryptocarpae<\u> & <u>Phanerocarpae<\u>. But whatever its 
appearance it will be always found to be composed of two  membranes, 
an inner and an outer. These differ but little in structure - both 
are cellular, but the inner, is in general, softer, less transparent 
and more richly ciliated while it usually contains but few 
thread cells - The outer, on the other hand, is dense, transparent 
and either distinctly cellular or developed into a muscular membrane 
It may be ciliated or not but it is usually thickly beset with thread cells 
either scattered through its substance or concentrated upon more 
or less raised papillae developed from its surface. 
[paragraph].8 I would wish to lay particular stress upon the composition 
of these and other organs of the Medusae out  of <u>two distinct membranes<\u> 
as I believe <s>it to be<\s> that it is one of the essential peculiarities of their structures 
and that a knowledge of the fact is of great importance in 
investigating their homologies - I will call these two membranes 
as such and independently of any modification into particular 
organs "foundation membranes" 
[paragraph]. 9 Where the stomach is attached to the disc the outer membrane 
passes into the general substance of the disc while the inner becomes 
continuous with the lining membrane of the canals - there is 
a larger or smaller space between the inner aperture of the stomach 
and the openings of the canals - with which both communicate 
and which I will therefore call the "common cavity" 
[paragraph].10. In the <u>Rhizostomidae<\u> the structure of the stomachs is fundamentally 
the same - but they are very minute and are collected upon the edges
